Content: In the image showing the wire spinning, energy is being converted from one form to another. In your answer folder, choose the option that correctly matches each part of the electric motor with the role it plays in the conversion of energy.

Key.Rationale:
The battery produces electrical energy.
The wire coil transmits the electric current.
The magnet causes the wire coil to spin and converts electrical energy to motion energy.

Content: Which device could be operated with a similar conversion of electrical energy to motion energy?

Key.Rationale: This option convert electrical energy into either sound or light energy.
A toy car converts electrical energy to motion energy, while the three other foils all convert electrical energy into either sound or light energy.
This option convert electrical energy into either sound or light energy.
This option convert electrical energy into either sound or light energy.

Content: Which observation provides evidence that student 1 threw the ball with more energy than student 2?

A.Choice: The ball bounced back closer to student 1 than student 2.

Key.Rationale: More energy will cause the ball to bounce farther away from the wall, which would cause the ball to land closer closer to Student 1, as shown in the figure.

B.Choice: The ball bounced back closer to student 2 than student 1.

Key.Rationale: This option is invalid based on the diagram.

C.Choice: The ball hit the wall at a higher point for student 1 than student 2.

Key.Rationale: This option is invalid based on the diagram; both students hit the ball against the wall at the same height.

D.Choice: The ball hit the wall at a higher point for student 2 than student 1.

Key.Rationale: This option is invalid based on the diagram; both students hit the ball against the wall at the same height.

Content: A student claims that the soccer ball has less energy after it hits the wall. Explain if this claim is true.
Complete the sentence by choosing the correct answers from the boxes.
When the soccer ball hits the wall, :DD-1: of the soccer ball's energy is transferred to the air in the form of :DD-2: .

Key.Rationale: If all of the energy were transferred, the ball would not have enough energy to bounce back away from the wall.
Only some of the ball's energy is transferred to the air as sound.
If none were transferred, a sound would not be produced.
Light is not produced at all.
Only some of the ball's energy is transferred to the air as sound.

Content: A student claims that sand is better than salt to treat snow-covered winter roads. Which statement ùóïùóòùó¶ùóß supports this claim?

A.Choice: Sand has no negative environmental effects.

B.Choice: Sand melts ice and is less expensive than salt.

C.Choice: Sand provides grip for tires and melts ice on roads.

D.Choice: Sand provides grip for tires and is less expensive than salt.

Key.Rationale: The table shows that tires skid less because sand helps the tires grip the road, and sand is also less expensive than salt. The table also states that sand does not melt ice and has some environmental impacts, making the other options invalid.

Content: For each road condition given, indicate whether sand or salt is the better treatment.

Key.Rationale: Sand helps the tires grip the road and salt does not help melt snow-covered roads when the air temperature is below 10¬∞F.
Salt works when the temperature is above 10¬∞F.
Sand would be better, since the temperature is below 10¬∞F, and salt only works when the temperature is above 10¬∞F. Sand helps the tires grip the road.

Content: Which statement describes how the brightness of light relates to distance?

A.Choice: The less bright the street light appears, the closer the student is to it.

Key.Rationale: Table 1 shows street light X is closest to the student (1 km), and it appears the brightest (medium). This option is the opposite, therefore invalid.

B.Choice: The brighter the street light appears, the closer the student is to it.

C.Choice: The less bright the star appears, the closer it is to Earth.

Key.Rationale: Table 2 shows similar information as Table 1 for the relative distance and brightness of stars. The farther away the star is, the less bright it appears. This option is opposite of the information in the table, and therefore invalid.

D.Choice: The brighter the star appears, the farther it is from Earth.

Key.Rationale: Table 2 shows similar information as Table 1 for the relative distance and brightness of stars. The farther away the star is, the less bright it appears. This option is opposite of the information in the table, and therefore invalid.

Content: Describe how the brightness of a star appears to change because of distance.
Complete the sentences by choosing the correct answers from the boxes.
Based on Tables 1 and 2, street light :DD-1: has the same brightness as Arcturus. If the student moves away from Arcturus, the brightness of this star would appear to :DD-2: .

Key.Rationale: Tables 1 and 2 show street light Z's brightness is ‚Äúvery low,‚Äù which is the same level of brightness as Arcturus.
The farther away the star, the less bright it appears. The Sun is the closest star and its brightness is very high.

Content: Which claim is accurate?

A.Choice: The Sun appears smaller and brighter than other stars because it is the closest star to Earth.

B.Choice: The Sun appears larger and brighter than any other star because it is the closest star to Earth.

Key.Rationale: Table 2 shows that the Sun appears larger because it is the closest star to Earth and it is the brightest.

C.Choice: The Sun appears larger and less bright than other stars because it is the farthest star from Earth.

D.Choice: The Sun appears smaller and less bright than any other star because it is the farthest star from Earth.

Content: Which is a valid statement, based on the map?
The ùóõùóúùóöùóõùóòùó¶ùóß risk of an earthquake happening is

Key.Rationale: The West Coast consists mainly of yellow and orange areas, which, according to the earthquake risk scale, represent the highest risk for earthquakes.
This option contains mostly light or dark green areas with some yellow. According to the risk scale, these colors represent a lower risk than the orange color of the West Coast.
This option contains mostly light or dark green areas with some yellow. According to the risk scale, these colors represent a lower risk than the orange color of the West Coast.
This option contains mostly light or dark green areas with some yellow. According to the risk scale, these colors represent a lower risk than the orange color of the West Coast.

Content: Based on the map, choose the option that shows the locations in correct order from ùóõùóúùóöùóõùóòùó¶ùóß (top) to ùóüùó¢ùó™ùóòùó¶ùóß (bottom) risk of an earthquake happening.

A.Choice:
Northern Alaska
Northern Central United States
Northern New Jersey
Southern New Jersey
Southern portion of the West Coast

B.Choice:
Southern portion of the West Coast
Northern Alaska
Northern New Jersey
Southern New Jersey
Northern Central United States

Key.Rationale: According to the earthquake risk scale, the southern portion of the West Coast has the highest risk for earthquakes, because the colors are mostly orange and yellow. The northern coast of Alaska is next, as the colors are mostly yellow and dark green. Northern NJ is next because the color is dark green. Southern NJ is next because the color is light green. The upper Midwest is last because that area is light blue.

C.Choice:
Northern New Jersey
Southern New Jersey
Northern Alaska
Southern portion of the West Coast
Northern Central United States

D.Choice:
Northern Central United States
Southern New Jersey
Northern New Jersey
Northern Alaska
Southern portion of the West Coast

Content: Locations where earthquakes occur are found around the world, but when viewed on a map, they are observed to follow a pattern.
The map shows five locations numbered 1 to 5. Identify the two locations where major earthquakes would ùó†ùó¢ùó¶ùóß ùóüùóúùóûùóòùóüùó¨ occur in the future.
problems/NJG5S/media/12a.jpg
Select the ùóßùó™ùó¢ correct locations from the five options.

Key.Rationale: As shown on the map, this area has experienced numerous major earthquakes since 1900. Also, it is along continental boundaries where two tectonic plates are colliding, making earthquakes occur.
This option is not located on or directly next to a continental plate boundary.
This option is not located on or directly next to a continental plate boundary.
As shown on the map, this area has experienced numerous major earthquakes since 1900. Also, it is along continental boundaries where two tectonic plates are colliding, making earthquakes occur.
This option is not located on or directly next to a continental plate boundary.

Content: This item has two parts. First, answer Part A. Then answer Part B.
Researchers count deer at the same time and same locations each year. Using the data in Table 1, choose the bar graph showing the number of deer recorded for each given year.

Key.Rationale: The table shows the following data: the population increased from 75,000 in 1850, to 85,000 in 1950, to 95,000 in 1970.

Content: Select from the boxes to describe the pattern shown in the deer population data.
The deer population :DD-1: until 1990 and then the population started :DD-2: .

Key.Rationale: In 1990, the population reached the highest number at 190,000, but it then decreased to 115,000 in 2010.
In 1990, the population reached the highest number at 190,000, but it then decreased to 115,000 in 2010.

Content: Which questions should scientists study in order to best understand the changing deer populations throughout the last 25 years?
Select the ùóßùó™ùó¢ of the five questions.

Key.Rationale: This option would not have an effect on the deer population.

B.Choice: Has the average size of a deer changed?

Key.Rationale: This option would not have an effect on the deer population.

C.Choice: How much deer habitat has been lost to housing development?

Key.Rationale: This option would affect the change in the deer population.

D.Choice: Has the number of the deer's natural predators changed?

Key.Rationale: This option would affect the change in the deer population.

E.Choice: Why does the color of the deer's coat change from summer to winter?

Key.Rationale: This option would not have an effect on the deer population.

Content: Town planners in New Jersey have created possible solutions to reduce the deer population. Based on the data in Table 1, in what year did these programs first start showing results

Key.Rationale: The table shows the population of deer decreased from 190,000 in 1990 to 155,000 in 2000, so the decrease in population indicates the program showed results due to the decrease in the population.

Content: The development of land has caused the deer populations in some parts of New Jersey to more than triple over the past years. Deer density is how many deer are counted in a specific area. Table 2 shows the deer density and land development levels for a location in Mercer County, NJ.
problems/NJG5S/media/16a.jpg
Based on Table 2, predict how deer populations and land development affect people and their environment.
Complete the sentences by choosing the correct answers from the boxes.
Deer density :DD-1: as land development increases. This is a result of :DD-2: deer in the specific area, which causes a(n) :DD-3: in problems for people and their environment.

Key.Rationale: The table shows as land development increases (high), the number of deer per acre also increases.
As the number of deer per acre increases, there are more deer found on the same amount of land.
As there are more deer found on the same amount of land, this will most likely cause more problems for the human population.

Content: Many New Jersey towns have started programs to decrease the deer population and reduce the negative effects that deer are having on people and the environment.
Some of the solutions to decrease deer populations are shown in Table 3.
problems/NJG5S/media/17a.jpg
Choose ùóßùó™ùó¢ solutions for reducing deer populations and explain why each of these solutions would be more effective than the solutions not chosen.
Also, explain why each of the other two solutions would be less effective.
This item has two parts. First, answer Part A. Then answer Part B.
Using Table 1, select the option that shows the weight of the water for each 6-hour period.

Key.Rationale: The bar graph shows the weight of the water remains the same at 100 grams over the 24-hour time period.

Content: Describe the pattern in the weight of the water over time.
Complete the sentence by choosing the correct answer from the box.
The weight of the water :DD-1: .

Key.Rationale: Phase change does not affect the weight of the water.

Content: Students want to conduct a new investigation using a larger bag of water. Using Table 1, predict the weight of 300 grams of water after 72 hours.
Complete the sentences by choosing the correct answer from each box.
In the new investigation, the weight of water is predicted to be :DD-1: grams after 72 hours. This demonstrates that :DD-2: in a system over time.

Key.Rationale: Even though the water will remain in the freezer 72 hours instead of 24 hours, the weight of the water will still be 300 grams, showing the weight of matter is conserved.
Even though the water will remain in the freezer 72 hours instead of 24 hours, the weight of the water will still be 300 grams, showing the weight of matter is conserved.

Content: This item has two parts. First, answer Part A. Then answer Part B.
Using Table 1, select the option that shows the weight of the water for each 6-hour period.

Key.Rationale: According to the Age of Fossils table, archaeopteryx lived for 85 million years, ammonite lived for 175 million years, blastoid lived for 232 million years, and trilobite lived for 280 million years.

Content: Identify the organism that lived for the shortest amount of time and then determine the type of environment that organism inhabited.
Complete the sentence by choosing the correct answer from the box.
The organism that likely lived on Earth for the shortest time lived in a :DD-1: environment.

Key.Rationale: Archaeopteryx lived the shortest amount of time and it was a land organism.

Content: Scientists discovered two additional fossils, Fossil X and Fossil Y, at Location 1. The approximate ages of the fossils were determined and are shown in Table 1.
problems/NJG5S/media/21a.jpg
Based on Figure 1 and Table 1, describe how the environment changed at Location 1 over time.
Complete the sentence by choosing the correct answer from each box.
Based on fossil evidence, Location 1 changed to a :DD-1: environment :DD-2: million years ago.

Key.Rationale: According to the Age of Fossils table, ammonite was a marine organism in Location 1 that lived 65 million years ago. Looking at Table 1, Additional Fossil Information, fossils of a leaf and archaeopteryx, both land organisms, lived in Location 1 between 50 and 60 million years ago.
Location 1 was land at least 60 million years ago. Somewhere between 60 and 65 million years ago, Location 1 changed from marine to land.

Content: Based on Figure 1, identify which questions can be answered by analyzing the data.

Key.Rationale: By looking at the type of fossils that were found at each location, it can be determined whether the organisms lived in either a marine or a land environment.
There are no data in the Age of Fossils table that describe the type of climate or how the climate may have changed in each location.
Only the type of fossils are shown in the Age of Fossils table, not how many were found at each location.
The different types of fossils are identified in the Age of Fossils table.

Content: A student claims that the fossils at one of the locations provide evidence that the environment had changed. Identify the information that supports this claim.
Complete the sentence by choosing the correct answer from each box.
At Location :DD-1:, the fossils of the :DD-2: show the area had species that :DD-3: .

Key.Rationale: The types of fossils (ammonite and trilobite) at Location 1 were both created from marine organisms.
The fossils at Location 2 (archeopteryx and blastoid) were created from both terrestrial and marine organisms, therefore in that location the environment changed.
The fossils at Location 2 (archeopteryx and blastoid) were created from both terrestrial and marine organisms, therefore in that location the environment changed.

Content: Based on Table 1, select the option that shows cities that have been correctly paired with another city that has similar annual precipitation.

A.Choice:
Adak and Riyadh

Richland and Tehran

Needles and Klaksvik

Los Angeles and Athens

B.Choice:
Adak and Klaksvik

Richland and Tehran

Needles and Riyadh

Los Angeles and Athens

Key.Rationale:
Annual precipitation in Adak is 61 inches and annual precipitation in Klaksvik is 56 inches.
Annual precipitation in Richland is 7 inches and annual precipitation in Tehran is 9 inches.
Annual precipitation in Needles is 4 inches and annual precipitation in Riyadh is also 4 inches.
Annual precipitation in Los Angeles is 16 inches and annual precipitation in Athens is also 16 inches.

C.Choice:
Adak and Athens

Richland and Klaksvik

Needles and Tehran

Los Angeles and Riyadh

D.Choice:
Adak and Klaksvik

Richland and Athens

Needles and Riyadh

Los Angeles and Tehran

Content: Which statement is ùóïùóòùó¶ùóß supported by the data?

A.Choice: Adak and Tehran are far from each other and have similar temperatures.

Key.Rationale: Adak and Tehran are far from each other, but their average highs are very different. Adak's average high temperature is 52¬∞F and Tehran is 81¬∞F.

B.Choice: Needles and Riyadh are far from each other and have similar temperatures.

Key.Rationale: Needles and Riyadah are far from each other. Their average high temperatures are the same at 95¬∞F and their average low temperatures are similar at 54¬∞F and 57¬∞F respectively.

C.Choice: Needles and Riyadh are far from each other and have very different temperatures.

Key.Rationale: Needles and Riyadah are far from each other, but their average high and low temperatures are very similar.

D.Choice: Needles and Richland are far from each other and have very different temperatures.

Key.Rationale: Needles and Richland are close to each other, yet have very different average temperatures.

Content: A student makes claims about which cities have climates that are very similar to each other. Based on Table 1, identify which claims are supported by the data.

Key.Rationale: Neither Athens nor Tehran have the greatest amount of precipitation. Adak has the greatest amount of precipitation at 61 inches.
Adak and Klaksvik both have the same average high temperature of 52¬∞F.
Klaksvik and Tehran both have the same average low temperature of 37¬∞F.
Neither Richland nor Los Angeles have the lowest amount of precipitation. Riyadh and Needles have the lowest amount of precipitation at 4 inches.

Content: Figure 2 shows the location of Newark, NJ, in relation to the other eight cities.
problems/NJG5S/media/S9a.jpg
Table 2 shows the average climate data for Newark, NJ.
problems/NJG5S/media/S9b.jpg
Compare the climate data of Newark to the other eight cities. Based on the data, identify the two cities that have a climate most similar to Newark and describe their climate.
Complete the sentences by choosing the correct answer from each box.
The two cities that have the most similar climate to Newark are :DD-1: . They are all similar because they all have :DD-2: conditions than other cities.

Key.Rationale: The average high and low in Klaksvik are 52¬∞F and 37¬∞F, with 56 inches of precipitation per year. The average high and low in Adak are 52¬∞F and 32¬∞F, with 61 inches of precipitation per year. The average high and low in Newark are 63¬∞F and 46¬∞F, with 46 inches of precipitation per year. Even though the temperatures are similar, the precipitation for Newark is more similar to the precipitation in Klaksvik and Adak.
Newar, Klasvik, and Adak are cooler and have more precipitation than the other cities listed.

Content: A student claims that potatoes can be successfully grown without soil. Based on Table 1, which statements ùóïùóòùó¶ùóß support this claim?
Select ùóßùó™ùó¢ of the five statements.

A.Choice: The heaviest potatoes were grown in soil.

Key.Rationale: The heaviest potatoes were grown in soil but this does not support the claim that potatoes can be successfully grown without soil.

B.Choice: The greatest number of potatoes were grown in air.

Key.Rationale: The greatest number of potatoes were grown in air (28), therefore soil is not needed.

C.Choice: Both water and air produced the same average weight per potato.

Key.Rationale: Both water and air produced the same average weight per potato (12 grams), which shows that potatoes can be successfully grown without soil.

D.Choice: Both soil and air produced plants with a greater total weight than water.

Key.Rationale: Although it is true that both soil and air produced plants with greater total weight than water, this does not support the claim that potatoes can be successfully grown without soil.

E.Choice: Both soil and water produced the same average number of potatoes per plant.

Key.Rationale: Although it is true that both soil and water produced the same average number of potatoes per plant, this does not support the claim that potatoes can be successfully grown without soil.

Content: The soil was weighed at the beginning and end of the experiment. The weight did not change.
This is evidence that potato plants mainly get what they need for growth from the

Key.Rationale: Since the weight of the soil did not change from the beginning to the end of the experiment, the soil therefore did not provide the majority of nutrients to the plants. This is the only option that does not include soil.

Content: Figure 2 shows how plants use their leaves to make food for growth in a natural environment.
problems/NJG5S/media/30a.jpg
Based on Figure 1 and Figure 2, explain what plants need in their natural environment for growth.
Complete the sentence by choosing the correct answer from each box.
In their natural environment, plants need the energy from :DD-1: in order to use :DD-2: to make their own food for growth.

Key.Rationale: In nature, plants do not receive energy from air.
In nature, plants do not receive energy from soil.
In nature, plants do not receive energy from water.
In nature, plants receive energy from sunlight.
Plants use water and air, not soil, to make food.
Plants use water and air, not soil, to make food.
Plants use water and air, not soil, to make food.
Plants use water and air, not soil, to make food.

Content: Which questions could the students be attempting to answer based on the investigations shown?
Select ùóßùó™ùó¢ of the five questions.

A.Choice: Does changing the height of the ramp affect the speed of the marble?

Key.Rationale: The height of the ramp changes from 30 centimeters in Investigation 1 to 60 centimeters in Investigation 2, so this is a possible question.

B.Choice: Does changing the height of the ramp affect the weight of the marble?

Key.Rationale: The weight of the marble does not change in either investigation.

C.Choice: Does changing the height of the ramp affect the path the marble takes?

Key.Rationale: The path the marble takes does not change in either investigation.

D.Choice: Does changing the height of the ramp affect how far the 0.1 kg weight is pushed?

Key.Rationale: The height of the ramp changes from 30 centimeters in Investigation 1 to 60 centimeters in Investigation 2 and there is a measuring tape at the end of the ramp, so this is a possible question.

E.Choice: Does changing the height of the ramp affect where the 0.1 kg weight begins to move?

Key.Rationale: Even though the height of the ramp changes from 30 centimeters in Investigation 1 to 60 centimeters in Investigation 2, the weight is placed at 0 centimeters on the tape for both investigations.

Content: In Investigation 2, predict the results if the weight of the marble increases. Provide an explanation for the prediction.
In Investigation 2, the height of the ramp and the marble remain the same. Predict the results if a 0.2 kg weight is used. Provide an explanation for the prediction.
Describe the results of Investigations 1 and 2.
Complete the sentences by choosing the correct answer from each box.
In Investigation 1, the speed of the marble at the collision with the 0.1 kg weight was :DD-1: the speed of the marble in Investigation 2.
In Investigation 2, the energy transferred from the marble to the 0.1 kg weight was :DD-2: the energy transferred from the marble to the 0.1 kg weight in Investigation 1.

Key.Rationale: The speed of the marble in Investigation 1 is less than Investigation 2 because the ramp is not as high.

The energy transferred from the marble to the weight in Investigation 2 was greater (shown by the weight being moved farther along) than in Investigation 1, because more speed means more energy transferred.

Content: Investigation 3 changes the ramp size. The new ramp will be 90 centimeters in length and 15 centimeters in height.
The students make four claims based on the results of Investigation 3. Based on Figure 1, identify if each claim is or is not supported by the data.

Key.Rationale: The marble will make less noise in Investigation 3 because the marble will be moving slower, therefore less energy will be transferred and less noise created.
The marble will have less energy in Investigation 3 because the marble will be moving slower.
The marble will move slower down the ramp in Investigation 3 because the marble will have less energy.
The marble will not move the same distance after it hits the weight because it will have less energy.
